Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 12:38PM drwendy wrote: Not sure, but here's a bump.  I'm sure your docs would not be bumping up your surgery if they didn't feel it was the right thing to do for you.  Hopefully the taxol has had a chance to do its job by now and you'll do great in the long run. Good luck!
Posts.Title: heart issues so no more chemo pinker drwendy

Posts.Content: drwendy wrote: Oh boy.  Just got my first of 6 treatments of taxotere, cytoxan and adriamycin on Tuesday and I'm still wiped out on Friday.  Weak and shaky and that lovely neulasta bone pain isn't helping.  Anybody had this combo?  Anyone hazard a guess when I'm not going to feel like cat butt anymore?  I thought I was stronger than this. Dx 11/3/2011, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: someone please tell me this gets better... drwendy Racy

Posts.Content: drwendy wrote: Hello athletic BC survivors!  I've just finished 6 rounds of TAC which took me from a marathon runner to a person who gets winded rubbing on skin lotion.  I can jog..very slowly...for about 50 yards before I have to walk.  I'm wondering if the chemo has set me back to a pre-running state (only stared 4 years ago and remember celebrating my first solid single mile without having to stop) and I'll have to start over from nothing or if my body will retain some muscle memory and my heart will get back to normal once all the poison is out of my system?  I just had my final treatment last Tuesday, still have double mastectomy and radiation to go.  Thanks for any advice! Dx 11/3/2011, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Athletes, how fast will stamina come back? drwendy sanbar8771

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 01:32PM drwendy wrote: All you northern girls, it's Cincinnati here!  I'm more than halfway through neoadjuvant chemo, just finished round 4 out of 6.  Two more hits, then it's bye bye boobies, can't wait to get them off me. Then radiation and then a rebuild somewhere down the line.  This site has been a huge help to me through chemo and at least we can go through it together!
Posts.Title: Ohio Chemo Sisters Kelloggs Kelloggs

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2012 10:53AM drwendy wrote: I am 5 days out from my BMX and have slept in my own bed propped up with pillows (don't forget one under your knees) since my first night home (only once night in hospital post-op).  The drains are super-annoying but I have no trouble walking around, doing stairs, fixing my own lunch etc.  You won't be an invalid after this procedure, just a bit sore and very annoyed by your drains.  I went clothes-shopping yesterday and paging through racks of clothes made me a bit sore, but overall it really hasn't been too awful for me.  I'm feeling guilty for taking 2 full weeks off from work since I really don't think I'll need them.
Posts.Title: Main Level or Upstairs Bedroom for BMX Recovery? PhotogAmy drwendy

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2012 01:26PM drwendy wrote: I am 5 days out from BMX and so glad I did it.  We knew about the 5 cm mucoid IDC in the right breast but ALL the testing (breast MRI, mammo, ultrasound, cat scan) missed the OTHER 5 mm IDC in the same breast.  These tests are NOT foolproof.  My left breast came up clean in the pathology but I'm glad it's gone for the reasons you have all listed...less breast cells to make new cancers, no mammograms in my future....but also for practical reasons.   Had I kept my saggy 40-year-old D cup on the left side I would now (5 days post-surgery) have to either wear a bra to hold up the left side with a foob on the empty right whenever I go out (ouch, I want NOTHING touching the surgical site now) or just let saggy lefty swing under a shirt (nobody wants to see that).   And the same during radiation when I'll be back at work....bra with foob over my sure-to-burn pale right side skin (ouch ouch ouch) or lefty sagging grossly under my clothing at the office.  This might sound vain or superficial, but for a larger busted woman it's not.  This way I'm flat now, and when they do my recon they'll grow with TE's at the same rate and be swapped out the same.   I know rads means they might not be perfectly symmetrical, but heck, they weren't perfectly symmetrical to begin with.  I am VERY happy with my decision to take both off at once and would encourage anyone considering UMX to think very carefully about the possibility of having to deal with all this post-surgery bullcrap more than once.
Posts.Title: Unilateral vs. Bilateral MX: regrets? jgisme GreenEyes57

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 05:15PM drwendy wrote: I am on taxotere, adria and cytoxan and it's not THAT bad.  They'll check your heart first and as long as they don't take you over your lifetime adria maximum (and they won't), the risk to heart function is minimal.  There's always a risk of other cancers after chemo, and I don't think that's unique to adriamycin.  If your MO thinks it's the most appropriate drug for the cancer you have, then I would not let worries slow you down, this is the cancer you have NOW and if you aren't aggressive enough in treating it, you won't have that future to worry about.  Better to be bald and tired (like me) and alive!  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: AC and T chemo stella0926 dawn31337

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2012 03:37PM drwendy wrote: I love the "abbie" style of pre-tied scarf from turban plus.  It doesn't have the hangie-down ends that get in the way of my stethoscope at work, and they look pretty cute.  I also love Buffs, and other fashion scarves.  I never bought a wig and don't intend to, my chemo buddy called hers her "dead raccoon."  I also have a soft felt camo sleeping hat given to me by a friend.  I never wore hats or scarves at all before chemo...it's a whole new world of accessories!
Posts.Title: What was your favorite head covering through chemo? BooBee Brendatrue

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2012 03:53PM drwendy wrote: I didn't use one and am bald, bald, bald.  But my onco warned me that the stuff would stay in my system and pass in my urine and other bodily fluids for days after each treatment, so it seems to me that freezing your noggin while getting your drip would only help a little.  I defer to anyone who actually used one, but remember that not all the chemo drugs cause total hair loss anyway.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Hair loss prevention Mimi8 Ang7

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2012 02:11AM - edited Oct 7, 2012 02:12AM by drwendy This is such a personal issue, only you can decide.  I was a 34 D 40 year old marathon runner when they told me I had IDC on the right side and it was too big for lumpectomy.  I knew immediately that they both had to go for a variety of reasons.  Medically I know that the conditions that led to me developing BC on the right side (genetics? environment? hormones? pollutants?) have all been exactly the same on the left side and the fact that it wasn't showing any tumors didn't mean that it wasn't just as cancer-prone as the right. I went through chemo before my surgery and that's enough to make sure you'll do anything in the world to help prevent future cancers.  My surgeon did not want to take the healthy lefty, but I was adamant and I'm so glad.  Practically speaking, having both off is no more difficult than having one.  You're still off work for 2 weeks, you still have stupid drains, you still have lifting restrictions for a while.  They don't take nodes on the non-cancer side so the lymphedema risk is extremely low.  The recovery is the same whether it's one or two gone.  Do you need radiation?  Because I can't imagine how awful it would have been to have the horrific armpit burns that radiation gave me and still have needed to be wearing a bra to support one floppy leftover D cup (or to go to work braless with one floppy leftover D cup...nobody wants to see that).  Now that I'm all healed up I can run and ride horses with no bra and it's great.  I have foobs (cute little B's!) that I wear under regular clothes and they're fine.  I'm gearing up for reconstruction with Dr. Khouri in Miami who is going to build me two cute new boobs out of my butt fat.  All in all I have never regretted the loss of my healthy left boob for one single second and it was absolutely the right decision for me.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: To be flat or uniboob, please help Frapp Lily55

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 04:41PM drwendy wrote: I'd be scared NOT to do chemo...I feel like it's my best weapon.  I'm in the middle of every 3 week Adria/cytoxan/taxotere treatment, just finished 4/6 treatments.  I ran and walked half of a marathon 5 days after treatment 3 with my oncologist's blessing.  I'm not fast, but I did it and Disney gave me a medal anyway!  I'm tired and sick sometimes but I work full time and it's manageable.  If they want to do chemo, LET THEM...do you really want to hear from this AGAIN?
